content.description:
Figure 1. Incidence of protoporphyria in a particular family

Protoporphyria is a genetic disorder characterized by an extreme sensitivity to sunlight. One form of protoporphyria is caused by a mutation in the <math alttext="A L A S 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>S</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">2</mn></mrow></math> gene that results in the accumulation of protoporphyrin, an organic compound, in the blood, liver, and skin. The pedigree in Figure 1 shows the incidence of protoporphyria in a particular family.
content.question:
One mutation in <math alttext="A L A S 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>S</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that is associated with protoporphyria is a four-nucleotide deletion. The protein expressed from the mutant allele is <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> amino acids shorter than the wild-type protein.
Which of the following best explains why a shortened protein is produced?

choices.label: The mutation disrupts the start codon, preventing the ribosome from beginning translation.
The mutation introduces a premature stop codon, causing translation to end early.
The mutation changes the geneâ€™s regulatory region, causing unregulated gene expression.
The mutation affects posttranscriptional modifications by preventing the removal of introns.

content.answer: The mutation introduces a premature stop codon, causing translation to end early.
